Mechanics.definition: Rate of change of velocity
The distance travelled by the car after the brakes are applied until the car stops
The fritctional force applied by the road on the tyre (in the opposite direction to the motion of the vehicle, that  brings the vehicle to rest)
The point on the object where the total weight (appears) to act
Resultant force = 0, Resultant torque = 0
Two equal but opposite forces acting along different lines
Density = Mass/Volume
A vector directed from initial position to final positions having magnitude equal to the distance between those points
KE and momentum are conserved
Average force applied multiplied by the time over which it acts
Momentum is conserved. KE after the collision is less than KE before the collision
1J is the work done by a force of 1N which acts over a distance 1m in the direction of the force
The linear momentum of a body is the "product of mass and velocity
Moment = force x perpendicular distance from pivot
1N is the force required to cause a mass of 1kg to have an acceleration of 1m/s^2
A body will remain at rest or continue to move with constant velocity unless acted on by a resultant force
The resultant force is directly proportional to the rate of change of momentum
When an object A exerts a force on an object B, object B will exert a force of equal magnitude, of the same nature but opposite in direction on object A
Rate of work done. Energy transferred per unit time
Pressure = Force/Area
Energy cannot be created or destroyed; it can only be transformed. Hence, the total energy of a system remains constant.
The total momentum before a collision is equal to the total momentum after the collision provided no external forces act on the system.
The sum of the clockwise moments must equal the sum of the anti-clockwise moments about any point in equilibrium
The vector sum of all the individual forces acting on an object
Thinking distance + Braking distance
One of forces x perpendicular distance between the forces
The distance travelled by the car in the time taken by the driver to react
A quantity with magnitude and direction
Rate of change of displacement
Watt is the power used when one joule of work is done per second
Force x distance moved in the direction of the force

Materials.definition: Has no plastic region - breaks at its elastic limit
Large plastic region - can be drawn into a wire
When exceeded, a permanent deformation will remain when the stress is removed
Extension is proportional to the force applied up to the limit of proportionality
The material doesn't return to its original length when the stress is removed
A stiff material has a high/large Young Modulus
Extension per unit original length
Tensile force per unit cross-sectional area perpendicular to the force
Can take a high (maximum) stress before breaking
The ratio of tensile stress to tensile strain when Hooke's Law is obeyed
Electrical energy transformed from other forms per unit charge
The energy acquired by an electron accelerated through a p.d. of 1V
The average displacement travelled by the electrons along the wire per unit time opposite to the direction of conventional current flow
The loss of voltage in the battery per unit current. The resistance of the internal components of a battery.
The energy transferred when a machine with a power of 1kW operates for a time of 1 hour
The total current into a junction equals the total current out (charge is conserved)
The sum of e.m.f.s equals the sum of the p.d.s around a closed loop in a circuit (energy is conserved)
For a conductor at constant temperature, the current flowing through the conductor is directly proportional to the potential difference across it
The energy transferred per unit charge from electrical to other forms
Energy transferred per unit time
Potential difference/current
(Resistance x Cross-sectional Area)/Length of wire

Electricity.definition: Electrical energy transformed from other forms per unit charge
The energy acquired by an electron accelerated through a p.d. of 1V
The average displacement travelled by the electrons along the wire per unit time opposite to the direction of conventional current flow
The loss of voltage in the battery per unit current. The resistance of the internal components of a battery.
The energy transferred when a machine with a power of 1kW operates for a time of 1 hour
The total current into a junction equals the total current out (charge is conserved)
The sum of e.m.f.s equals the sum of the p.d.s around a closed loop in a circuit (energy is conserved)
For a conductor at constant temperature, the current flowing through the conductor is directly proportional to the potential difference across it
The energy transferred per unit charge from electrical to other forms

Waves.definition: An antinode occurs on a standing wave at a point where the amplitude of the standing wave takes its maximum value
Waves are coherent if they have the same frequency and there is a constant phase difference between them
Two waves that meet at a point superpose resulting in the resultant (overall) displacement/intensity being changed from that of either of the waves individually
All wavelengths are present (in the radiation)
Wavefronts spread out after passing through a gap or around an obstacle
(Any) distance moved from the equilibrium position of a point/particle on a wave
Thre number of waves passing a point per unity time
Incident power per unit cross-sectional area
The displacement of particles is parallel to the direction of energy transfer
A node occurs at a point on a standing wave where the amplitude (and hence displacement) is always zero
Phase difference is an angular measure of how far one point on a wave is through the cycle when compared with another point on the same wave, or to another wave of the same frequency
A transverse wave where the oscillations are confined to a single plane
When two waves overlap, they superpose with the resultant displacement at a given point being equal to the vector sum of the displacements of the two individual waves at that point
A progressive wave is the transfer of energy without the transfer of matter occuring via oscillations
The displacement of particles is perpendicular to the direction of energy transfer
The minimum distance between two particles on the wave which have the same displacement and the same velocity at the same time

Quantum.definition: All wavelengths are present (in the radiation)

Quantum.term: de Broglie wavelength of an electron
Quantum.definition: Electrons show wavelike properties and the elctron's wavelength depends on its momentum according to \lambda=h/p, where \lambda is the wavelength, p the momentum and h is Planck's constant
The energy acquired by an electron accelerated through a p.d. of 1V
An allowed (quantised) energy state of an electron in an atom
Incident power per unit cross-sectional area
Light emitted from excited isolated atoms produces a line spectrum which consists of a series of distinct coloured lines against a dark background
Light absorbed by isolated atoms produces a line spectrum which consists of a series of distinct dark lines against a background of a continuous spectrum
A quantum of electromagnetic energy having E=hf, where E is the energy of the photon, f is its frequency and h is Planck's constant
Emission of electrons from a metal surface when photons are incident on the surface
The minimum frequency of incident light required for (photo)electrons to be emitted from a metal surface
The minimum energy required to remove an electron from the surface of a metal

Circular Motion & Oscillations.definition: Rate of change of angular displacement
An acceleration that will cause the body to follow a circular path. The acceleration is perpendicular to the velocity of the body.
A resultant force which acts on a body causing it to follow a circular path. The force acts perpendicular to the velocity of the body.
The resultant force acts perpendicular to the velocity
When a system returns to equilibrium in the shortest possible time without oscillating
The distance (and direction) of the body from the equilibrium position
The equilibrium position is the point where the resultant force on the oscillator is zero
Number of oscillations per unit time
An orbit with a period of 24 hours.
The time taken for an object to make one complete revolution
The time taken for an object to complete one full oscillation
One radian is the angle subtended at the centre of a circle by an arc equal in length to the radius of the circle
A body executes simple harmonic motion when its acceleration is directly proportional to its displacement from its equilibrium position and is directed towards the equilibrium position

Thermal.definition: For a fixed mass of gass at constant temperature the pressure of the gas is inversely proportional to its volume
The sum of random distribution of potential and kinetic energies of all the molecules
The energy supplied to melt a given quantity of a solid substance to liquid
The energy supplied to boil given quantity of a liquid substance to gas
The energy required to heat 1kg of a substance by 1K without a change of state
Two bodies are in thermal equilibrium if when placed in thermal contact there is not net flow of heat energy between them

Gravitational Fields.definition: An orbit with a period of 24 hours
Gravitational force per unit mass at a point in space
The work done per unit mass in moving a mass from infinity to a point in a gravitational field
The work done in moving a mass from infinity to a point in a gravitational field
The cube of the planet's distance from the sun is proportional to the square of the orbital period.
The force of attraction between two given particles is inversely proportional to the square of their separation and directly proportional to the product of their masses
The direction and strength of the field is constant throughout the considered region of space

Electric Fields and Capacitors.definition: Charge stored on a capacitor per unit voltage applied across it
The force between two point charges is proportional to the product of the charges and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them
Electrical force per unit positive charge
The work done per unit positive charge in bringing a charge from infinity to a point in an electric field
The work done in bringing a charge from infinity to a point in an electric field
A capacitor has a capacitance of 1 farad when it can store 1 coulomb of charge per volt
The time taken for the charge/current/p.d. to decay to 1/e of its initial value when a capacitor discharges

Magnetic Fields & Electromagnetism.definition: The induced e.m.f. is proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux linkage
A magnetic flux density produced by a current from an induced e.m.f. will always be such that it opposes the change in magnetic flux linkage that created it
The magnetic flux \phi = BA, where B is the magnetic flux density and A is the area normal to the field
B = F/ILsin\theta where F is the force on a wire of length L, carrying current I, at an angle \theta to the magnetic flux density B
\Phi = BAN, where B is the magnetic flux density, A is the area normal to the field and N is the number of turns on the coil
1T is the magnetic field strenght that results in a wire of 1m, carrying a current of 1A that is perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field experiencing a force of 1N
A magnetic field of flux density 1T passing normally through an area of 1m^2 produces a magnetic flux equal to 1Wb

Nuclear Physics.definition: Rate of decay of radioactive nuclei
The minimum energy needed to completely separate all the nucleons in a nucleus
The interaction of a photon with an orbital electron in an atom resulting in the electron being ejected from the atom and the photon being scatterd at a lower energy
The probability of decay of a nucleus per unit time
Particles that cannot be broken down into smaller/simpler components
The average time taken for the activity/number of unstable nuclei of a radioactive source to decrease to one half of its original value
(Two) atoms of the same element (hence with the same number of protons) but with different numbers of neutrons to each other
A specific nucleus, characterised by a certain number of protons and neutrons
The interaction of a photon with the nucleus of an atom resulting in the energy of the photon producing an electron-position pair

Astrophysics.definition: The average distance from the centre of the Earth to the centre of the Sun. 1AU=1.5x10^11m
The universe is homogeneous, isotropic and has universal laws of physics
The change in frequency/wavelength of a wave as detected by a received in relative motion to a source
The recessional velocity of distance galaxies is directly proportional to their distance from us
The distance travelled by light in a vacuum in 1 year. 1LY=9.5x10^15m
Distance at which 1AU subtends an angle of 1 arcsecond. 1pc=3.1x10^16m

Medical Imaging.definition: This occurs when the acoustic impedances of two media are similar/identical
The interaction of an X-ray photon with an orbital electron in an atom resulting in the electron being ejected from the atom and the X-ray photon being scattered at a lower energy
The change in frequency/wavelength of a wave as detected by a received in relative motion to the source
The thickness (of a particular material) needed to reduce the intensity of X-rays of a specific energy to one half of its original value
The interaction of an X-ray photon with the nucleus of an atom resulting in the energy of the photon producing an electron-positron pair
The application of potential difference across a material/crystal, causing an expansion/contraction
The interaction of an X-ray photon with an orbital electron in an atom resulting in the photon being completely absorbed by the electron which is then ejected from atom
